div.head: Studies
div.p: We store materials of interest to Ethiopian and Eritrean studies also as TEI.
For example for Ludolf's Commentarius and Historia.
Encoding practice for Textual Units apply, records for Studies should have in TEI a type with study.

Currently entities of this type originate from a workflow based on an available set of images of an out of copyright text which can be automatically transcribed. Please refer to the page on Transkribus. The output of the transcription and alignment of course does not follow the workflow used for manuscripts.

div.head: Specific features of the encoding of Studies
div.p: Having obtained a part or the entirety of the transcription you will have a starting point which may need further encoding detailed below. based on the encoding of the Commentarius.

All text is contained in the element body and in a div element with the attribute type and the value edition. The different parts of the text are contained in other div element with the attributes type, subtype, xml:id.
...
These can be used to reproduce the overall structure of the work, e.g. the sequence of title page, table of contents, indexes, etc. This type of structure can be encoded, at any level of depth which is appropriate to render the features of the printed resource. These divisions can in part be obtained from the transcription tool. The logic and structure is not the same, so maintaining text areas from a layout analysis will in most cases not be meaningful.

Sections of the work that contain indices can be encoded using the list element, containing different number of item elements.
A.
Abdelbakides Muhamed
Abraham Echelelensis Maronita
Abulbaracat Arabs

Other useful elements for encoding, based on the mise en page of the text, may be:
fw element, for the running head at the top of all pages where it does not function to introduce a new section of the work
label element, with the attributes type and place, to specify whether it is the paragraph number or the note number and where it is placed in the page
p44 Joh. Potken & Matth. Armenius Prooem. I. 6
Running header and navigation labels

Based on the structure of the work, the following elements may also be used:
p element, if the work is divided in paragraphs, with xml:id attribute, reporting the number of the paragraph;
ab element, if the work has footnotes, with type attribute and the value footnote,containing note elements, with xml:id attribute
note elements, with place attribute, for possible annotations placed in the margin of the page.
(a) ... (b) ...
inf.2.6.29. L. II.5 p.112b
Footnotes and marginal notes The pointer to the footnote can be encoded with a simple ref
(a)
For encoding internal and external references we can follow the indication on the page References. The same applies to references to the encoded study-entity.

For the quotations, a distinction must be made between literal and indirect quotations:
for literal quotations we use the quote element, accompanied by the source attribute and, if the quotation language differs from the text language, by the xml:lang attribute
Questa fatica di abbreviare un così copioso volume doveva esser data à persone intelligenti, e dotte.
here the source points to a bibl element in the text
Ramusius in praefatione
we can use the q element for indirect quotations, or translation of quotation, which are distinguished from the surrounding text. If we have an indirect quotation we can also use the attribute source to point to a bibliographic reference in the text. Tellezius autem eum passim meritò perstringit, quòd non solùm gloriosas Lusitanorum actiones obfuscare voluerit ...
This also points to an existing bibl encoded in the running text
Lib.I.c.I
p.2.b & 3.
In the case of quotation translations, we can use the q element with the type attribute and value traslation, and the attribute corresp to point to to the corresponding quotation
Les Abissins reclement et recherchent nostre Prince Zaga-Christ leur Catholique et legitimite Seigneur Habessini expectant & requirunt nostrum Principem Tzaga-Christum Catholicum & legitimum suum Dominum.
Quotation with translation
For both literary and indirect quotations we can use the source attribute to point to a bibl element which should be placed in different place of the text:
in the body:
De quo P. B. Tellezius scribit: II. 5. p. 112. a. Alvarezium composuisse stylo plano & sincero Historiam Aethiopiae ...
Encoded bibliographic reference in the running text
in the marginal note:
Tellezius enim diserte dicit: Naodum ultimum fuisse, qui ex hoc monte ad imperium pervenerit Lib.I c.17.p.45.
Marginal note with bibliographic reference
in the footnote:
qui scribunt: Damnatorum animas in Sabbato feriari, atque ignem infernalem tunc non urere, neque etiam foetere(r) (r) Buxtorf in Synagoga Jud. c. 16.
Footnote with bibliographic reference
